Entries.default: Clearing her throat once, and then again - Maia raises her eyes to yours when you glance over.
Perking up at attention, Ishiza takes a cautious hop closer. He tips his head to the side and fixes you with a scrutinizing glare.
"Just thought I'd mention that if Xoti and I weren't already..." Maia starts to say more, but cuts herself off.
"I'll go ahead and say it. You're halfway toward all right." Maia purses her lips and appraises you up and down.
"Ah... forget I said anything. It's not important." Maia coughs into her fist and glances away.
"Been meaning to say that if you and fish boy weren't already so chummy...." Maia starts to say more, but cuts herself off.
"Been trying to say that it's a pity you're already... accounted for, captain. You're halfways toward being a decent catch."
"You're not too shabby yourself, soldier."
"Just halfway? Is that really all?"
"A captain is better than my usual slim pickings, which is a bunch of lore college dropouts playing sailor."
"I know, but it's kind of you to say."

"Have you ever... Ugh. Dumb question, but here I go anyway." 

Maia folds her arms and shifts her weight from one foot to the other.
"You ever gotten close to someone, even though it just wasn't... ordinary?"
"Ah... it's not that I'm not flattered, but..."
"Say no more. I'll give you some room to breathe. Come on, Ishi." Maia clucks her tongue to summon Ishiza, pushing you to the periphery of her attention.
"A god stepped on me once."
"You mean like with another man?"
"If that's your idea of out of the ordinary then you need a lesson, my friend."
"Below deck, there are only two rules - keep it interesting and remember your bitter squash." She pats a pouch at her side.
"What I'm talking about is a scenario where a difference in rank can get in the way of... enjoying shore leave."
"Yeah, that about kicks the legs out from under 'ordinary,' doesn't it?"
"Ah, you mean a tryst between captain and crew."
"Has someone been a very bad sailor?"
"I think I see where this is going. Let's keep it professional, okay?"
"Yeah, that about covers it."
"I'm just... testing the direction of the wind, here. Best not to overthink it."
"This is like picking oakum." Sighing, Maia rolls her eyes.
"On [Player Ship], the captain gets to make the rules."
"The winds are calm, but they've been known to shift unexpectedly."
"Rank is important. Complications tend to get in the way."
"For what it's worth, I don't disagree. I was just curious."
"I think it's more important that we remain friends, Maia."
"Interesting answer. I like the sound of that authority."
"As winds do." She grins.

"I've enjoyed that sort of arrangement before. Nothing to suggest I won't enjoy it again someday."

Maia plants her hands on her hip and smiles to herself.
"And when he doesn't take to someone, neither do I."
"You're saying that someone would have to cozy up with your bird to..."
"I have to know how that works."
"What exactly does Ishiza look for in a... special friend?"
"Did I say that?" Maia folds her arms and raises her brow.
"Not everyone's a bird lover. That's fine - some days I can't stand another second of captain stinkfeathers."
"But Ishi and I are never parted for longer than a few breaths. Take that however you will."
"You're the one with a spyglass into people's souls. You tell me how it works."
"Noted for future reference. First I had some questions."
"Let's be off."
"Who's a good bird?"
"That'll be all. Carry on, bird."
Letting out a high-pitched warble, Ishiza tucks his beak in among his wing feathers.
"Can't believe I'm saying this, but I think I'd like to speak with your bird."
"I'm sure he'd tell you if you asked nicely."
[Try to read Ishiza's soul.]
No sooner do you bridge the distance to Ishiza's soul than he turns his cold, mismatched gaze toward you. The force of his attention hits you like a whip.

<ispeech>Well. This is unexpected.</ispeech>

A voice cuts through the din of your thoughts - a feminine one, accompanied by the sound of feathers rustling against each other.
[Whisper] "Hylea?"
Glancing in your direction, Maia frowns as you, to all outward appearances, whisper to yourself.
[Say nothing.]

<ispeech>What exactly did you set out to accomplish by peering into the soul of this noble creature?</ispeech>

Ishiza cocks his head.
[Whisper] "Maia suggested that Ishiza and I get on better terms."
[Whisper] "I thought that if I got the bird to like me then Maia would like me."
[Whisper] "Noble? Are we talking about the same Ishiza?"

<ispeech>I see.</ispeech>

A slight breeze ruffles Ishiza's feathers.
<ispeech>You should already know better than to trust everything Maia has to say.</ispeech>

<ispeech>You must put a great deal of faith in Maia to find yourself in this... situation. 

Are you so certain she deserves your trust?</ispeech>
<ispeech>While the Deadfire is being cut, cauterized, and trampled, it is charming to find someone who makes time for such elaborate foreplay.</ispeech>
[Try to feed Ishiza.]
As you open your pack, Ishiza hops closer, craning back his head to observe with interest.
His pupils narrow with desire as he catches a whiff of shark meat.

He turns away disappointed, scratching at the ground with his talons. 

Evidently you aren't carrying anything that he wants.
[Stop feeding Ishiza.]
He regards you with an inquisitive tilt of his head, shifting his gaze from your eyes to your pack.
[Swim some shark meat in his direction.]
"Now that is what I'd call a happy bird." Maia folds her arms and grins.
"Not to mention a fat bird. Pretty soon I'll have to roll him around like a cask of ale."
Pecking at it delicately at first, Ishiza tosses caution to the wind and devours the haunch of meat with wild abandon.
[Whisper] "Any advice that could help me out here?"
[Whisper] "I guess we're finished for now."
[Whisper] "I answered your question, now you answer mine. What are you doing in Ishiza's soul?"
<ispeech>Perhaps you don't know him as I do.</ispeech>

<ispeech>I can say for certain that this is a very hungry, overworked, and at times underappreciated bird.</ispeech>

Ishiza spreads open his wings, studying his own plumage with evident curiosity.

<ispeech>Beyond that, I leave the rest up to you.</ispeech>

You receive the mental impression of an amused shrug.
<ispeech>Observing. The one you call Ishiza makes for a convenient lens into your travels.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Try not to take it too personally.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Best of luck in your mating ritual, Watcher.</ispeech>
The presence pulls away, and you find yourself once again staring into the eyes of an alert if less-intelligent Ishiza.
[Whisper] "What are YOU doing here?"
<ispeech>I am asking the questions.</ispeech>

"Funny thing is that Ishi can get... particular about people." 

Maia glances down at her bird, hiding a tiny smile.
"I hope that was as amusing for you as it was for me." Maia folds her arms and grins.
"I had some questions."
"Let's be off."
"Hypothetically speaking, of course."
"I'll pass, but thanks all the same."
"Naturally. It's all hypothetical here."
"Are you saying... are we..."
"Captain, what did I just tell you about not overthinking this?"
"Hypothetically speaking, I mean." She clears her throat.
"Thank you, I think?"
"Harmless compliment, I promise."
"It's almost never ordinary for me."

<ispeech>Far be it for me to judge affection. Better that it bloom or wilt uninterrupted.</ispeech>

Hylea lets out a wistful sigh that manifests as a cool breeze around your neck.
[Whisper] "What's your take on Maia?"
Upon catching her name being spoken, Maia furrows her brow and glances your way again. She seems on the verge of speaking up, but then shakes her head and resumes her business.
<ispeech>Do you often turn to birds for relationship advice?</ispeech>
"Sooner rather than later, one hopes?"
"Depends on what's in front of me and what's on the horizon... captain."
"I don't think I'm interested in this sort of thing."
[Whisper] "First Ondra, now you? Are any of the gods not spying on me through my crewmates?"
<ispeech>I can think of one. But was your question rhetorical?</ispeech>
"Captain." Maia turns away, favoring you with a wink.
"I just get a feeling about certain people, no matter their equipment."
"What do you look for in a partner?"
"Let's be off."

Touching your arm, Maia surprises herself with the gesture and pulls her hand away just as fast. 

Her fingers felt callused and very warm.
"I can't say where this goes next. But I'm keen on where it is now."
"No."
"Maybe I'm doing a poor job of explaining myself."
"Try not to use any fowl language." Chuckling to herself, Maia steps back and gives you space.
"I usually go for the clever ones, though they're not always clever enough to tell that I'm available."
<ispeech>I sense that Maia does not easily allow others into her confidence. She is observing you closer than you might guess.</ispeech>
"I've enjoyed female company in the past, in case... for any reason... you were wondering."
"And before you ask, the answer is no." Maia grimaces at Tekēhu.
"Ekera, I said nothing!" Tekēhu looks from Maia to you, affronted.
"Of course."

<ispeech>She has much on her mind. This may all be a whimsical diversion.

That, or she is softening you up for the red work of her masters.</ispeech>

<ispeech>Ah... I babble. What does the goddess of creativity know of kith courtship?</ispeech>

Ishiza tips his head to the side and winks.
"A man will do in a pinch, as long as their best thinking comes from the appropriate brain."
"Women usually make for better conversation, not that this isn't its own kind of charming."
"Heh. What'd I tell you, Ishi?" She toes the bird affectionately.
"This is fun and all, but I think we should stop."
[Offer Ishiza some more shark meat.]
He accepts the offering eagerly, picking apart and forcing down the meat with untrammeled joy.
He looks up at you imploringly.
"Doesn't look like I have any more shark meat. Sorry."
Crestfallen, Ishiza hops away and focuses his attention elsewhere.
"Oh. You wanted something, captain?"
"You were the one trying to get my attention."
"Something on your mind?"
"No?"
"What, me?" Maia chuckles and crosses her arms.
"Well, if you've got a moment, then."
"I had some questions."
"Let's be off."
"You could say that."
"I haven't been a captain for very long, you know."
"Well, that's why we have these little chats."
You take this to mean that he is a very good bird.
<ispeech>A word of advice, Watcher.</ispeech>
<ispeech>He and Maia share that much in common, at least.</ispeech>
This time his look is determined, ravenous. He pecks at your belongings like he would a ripe carcass.
[Offer Ishiza some more shark meat.]
He flaps his wings and descends on the meat, throwing back his head to choke as much down in a single go as possible.
"I've never seen him so forlorn. Try not to tease my bird in the future."
"Are we on friendlier terms yet?"

"Let's say you've graduated to achieving the bare minimum of my favor."

Maia folds her arms and grins.
"Which is farther than most anyone gets."
"Where do we go from here?"
"Well..."
"Hey. Not so fast."
"I think we both want this as long as it's on our terms."
"I know I've been a little hesitant. I still am."
"It didn't take you long to open up to the idea at first. I like that eagerness."
"You struck me as hesitant before, but I guess you're warming to the idea of us being... something."
"It's important to me that every member of the crew is well-fed. Even the birds."
"That was good shark. Hope it counts for something."
"Mark of a good captain, I'd say."
"Well, I like a man who carries around raw meat. We have that going for us."
Entries.female: "Well, I like a woman who carries around raw meat. We have that going for us."

Entries.default: "Consider your performance... noted." Maia bites her thumbnail and smiles.
"Performance? Was this just a test?"
"You're talking to a competitive naval sharpshooter with a litter of brothers."
"Everything's a test. But you also fed my bird, which is just plain decent."
"Sounds nice when you say it like that. A little wholesome for my taste, but nice."
"This won't work if you keep tricking me into taking care of your pet."
"I just hope I pass your next test."
"Hey, aren't we both figuring this out as we go?"
"What about you? What do you fancy?" She cocks her head to the side.
"If Iovara was any indication, I go for heretics."
"I like a disciplinarian. Pallegina, for instance."
"I find myself unusually attracted to military sharpshooters."
"I like someone carefree but principled, like Serafen."
"I know I've been a little hesitant, but I like where this is going."
"So you're finally convinced that I won't steer us toward the rocks? Good."
"I know we're getting comfortable, but I could use a little space."
"Fair enough. I'd say we both deserve some distance."
"You're on track. Just try not to steer us into a sandbar... captain."
"Well. Someone clearly missed the point."
"However it pans out, thanks for taking the time. And... for the bird food."
"That's.... okay. Unusual choice."
"We're all slaves to our own nameless want, aren't we?" She shakes her head, grinning.
"That right?" She raises her finger to her lips and smiles.
"Interesting choice." Maia raises her brow. A smile slowly takes shape.
"A passionate free spirit like Xoti."
"Someone like Tekēhu. I mean... just look at him."
"I try not to think about it."
"Someone warm and practical, like Edér."
"Someone focused and complex like Aloth."
Pallegina clears her throat conspicuously and looks for something to occupy her attention. She finds it in a speck of dust on her armor.
"The cap mayhaps be the first swabby since Remaro to be recognizing my many strengths moral and ethical."
"Reckon I like you too, Watcher." She grins bright and brassy, cheeks a rosy pink.

"Ekera, just look at me!" 

Tekēhu grins and puffs out his chest.
"Whatever works." Edér shrugs with a smile.
"I like that much better than 'tedious and uptight.'"
"I don't blame you. Life gets in the way of that kind of thing often as not."
<ispeech>The prospect of sharing her company... I can tell from here that it intrigues.</ispeech>
<ispeech>You have not postured to her with the same enthusiasm. I wonder what she offers that you do not desire.</ispeech>
<ispeech>But you already know about that.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Or... didn't you know?</ispeech>
[Whisper] "Know what?"
[Say nothing.]
<ispeech>Perhaps it isn't for me to say. All in good time.</ispeech>
[Whisper] "That she's an assassin?"
[Say nothing.]
<ispeech>Such a heartless word for an occupation which takes great skill to practice well.</ispeech>
<ispeech>Put it out of mind for now.</ispeech>
"With everything going on at once, I wondered if... gods, if we could talk." Maia nurses her brow and sighs.
"Something on your mind?"
"You can talk to me about anything, Maia."
"Maybe later."
"You're a good captain. Maybe I don't say that enough."

"Later? You're making a lot of assumptions about how much time we have."

She closes her eyes and sighs.
"Before I unload my cargo onto your port... how about you let me buy you a drink?" Maia glances around the lounge.

"Can we take a detour to the Officers' Lounge in the Brass Citadel? I could use a drink."

Maia shrugs and tips her head.
"Let's be off."
"Maybe later, if we have time."

"Appreciate it, captain. Hope you don't mind if I gather my thoughts on the way."

She releases a heavy sigh and nods.
[Give her an ale.] "Nonsense. To loyal birds."
[Give her an ale.] "Here, to us."
"May our enemies get caught up in their talons." Maia winks over her mug.
"To a good ship and a better crew." She raises her drink, holding it there in solemn silence.
"Why don't you just tell me what's going on."
"Maybe you can do this without liquid courage. I'm not there yet."
She drains it in a single prolonged gulp and sighs, wiping off her mouth with the back of her hand.
"I'd like that."
She snaps her fingers and a server appears with a pair of foaming mugs.
"Won't any tavern do?"
"I'd feel cozier with my kind... away from the rest of the rabble?"
"I want to take my mind off what doesn't need to be there." Maia frowns to herself and shrugs.
"I tell you... something about all that open water." Maia shakes her head.
"What?"
"You're talking about Ondra's Mortar."
"The ocean in general, or...?"
[Say nothing.]
"Ondra's Mortar, I mean."
"No. I mean the Mortar." She takes another hearty swig.
"Knew you were clever." She takes another hearty swig.

"To the Mortar, and everything beyond it."

She raises her empty mug in a halfhearted fashion.

"Thank Berath we have you as our living compass.

"I'd say Rauatai plans to set sail, compass or no."
"And this concerns you?"
"Is this what you wanted to talk about?"
"I'm nothing without a good officer on board."
[Say nothing.]
"Suppose I wanted to talk about... uncertainty."
"But now... all I see is open water on all sides."
"Me and [Player Ship], we can be your constants."
"Someone's a sad drunk."
"It's a poor assassin who gets melancholy over death."

"Under different circumstances, I'd be aboard that aimless fleet.

"Likely as not to die."

"As things stand... I'm thankful to be under your command, captain."

She raises her mug, peering at you over its lip. When she realizes it's empty, she snaps her fingers and a server appears with another.
"Flatterer." Maia raises a fist to her mouth and burps.
"Funny thing is, I know you mean it. But I still worry."
"Sometimes I wonder if that's what you really want."

"While the powers of the Deadfire claw at each other's faces, you'll be digging through a god's body for your soul.

"I'll be..." 

She raises the mug and catches herself, pausing.

"In a campaign that keeps changing, being a part of your crew makes me feel like I have a hand on the wheel."

Half of the mug vanishes.
"You want the secret to a lady's heart? Insult her occupation. Ass."
"What's your point?"
"I'll show you a sad drunk." She hiccups and shakes her head.
"With all that uncertainty, do we even have room for... this?" She gestures from herself to you with her mug, sloshing its contents.
"We can make room. I know it isn't easy."
[Kiss her.]
"I'd like to think so."
"We have to keep our priorities in check. This is bigger than us."
"The Maia I know embraces uncertainty, measures it like the wind before firing a shot."
"Remind me to have you on hand the next time I get like this."
"Following orders."
"Well. Unemployed."
"Doing what I do best."
"I can tell there's something here worth clutching with both hands."
"I just don't see this working."

"Never fails. Whenever I focus beyond my sights, my aim goes off. 

"I can't let that happen." 

Maia sighs and nurses her brow. She snaps her fingers for a mug of water.

"We had our fun. I'll go back to looking and listening. 

"For what it's worth... I never told my boss about us."
"I'm sorry you feel that way. I thought we were something special."
"I had other questions."
"Let's be off."

"We were something, anyway. Don't worry about the drinks. I've got a running tab." 

She gestures to the bartender, but says no more to you.

"Ugh... I'm as full as a barrel. I should gather my thoughts in healthier ways, like knitting or taxidermy." 

She pats her stomach and smiles.
"So you were just tricking me into feeding Ishiza!"
"Yeah, well... good shark meat is hard to come by!" Maia covers her mouth to suppress a chuckle.

You lean in and plant your lips on hers. At first it feels like kissing a wooden board, but she softens in the end.

Before pulling back.
"I felt that one down to my toes, captain."
"I know what a kiss ought to feel like, captain. Your heart wasn't in it."
"I'm pouring my heart into every glass, captain. Don't just sip it."

"Captain... when we're standing at the helm, the ship feels unsinkable. I'm glad I get to cozy up to that feeling.

"Ishiza's glad too. Not that his opinion matters."
He shoots a quick glare at Edér.
He shoots a quick glare at Serafen.
[Drink your ale in silence.]
[Toast] "To the fleet."
[Toast] "To the chase of wayward gods."
"Why are we here, Maia?"
"You'll know as soon as I'm ready."
"To every friend who vanished beneath the waves." Maia raises her drink higher.
"May Eothas lose his footing and tumble down a sea trench."
[Toast] "To [Player Ship]."
"And to all who defy the Lady of Lament by sailing across her back."
"I didn't think so. I was hoping..." She cuts herself off and shakes her head.
"You're right. I guess I knew that from the beginning."
"Thank you for the discretion, Maia."
"Don't mention it. Really, don't. Withholding from a report can get me into trouble."
"Or sailing. We have plenty of that in our future."
"Or target practice."
"You could start by stuffing Ishiza."
"True, true."
"Shooting down gulls as we drift with the tide. I can get behind that."

"Wouldn't be the first time I considered it."

Blinking at the sudden swell of attention, Ishiza cocks his head and snaps his beak.
"Come on, you. Let's be off."

Hesitating a moment, Maia drags you into a hug and squeezes you like she's clinging to a mast in stormy weather. 

When she releases you, she has to catch her breath and tidy up her bun.
"I had other questions."

Hesitating a moment, Maia drags you into a hug and squeezes you like she's clinging to a mast in stormy weather. 

When she releases you, she has to catch her breath and tidy up her bun.
"Aye aye, captain."
"Sorry, it's... I'm not new to this, I'm just not used to sharing company longer than a single voyage."
"I don't want this to end. Do you feel like taking a walk, having some time to ourselves?"
"Might not be a bad idea. Once my head has cleared, I'm sure I'll think of an even better one."
"That sounds pleasant, Maia."
"Maybe another time. We have a lot to think about."

"Suit yourself, captain. There's space in our quarters for that sort of thing."

She clears her throat and smiles.

"We can just talk. And if it goes any further, we'll know exactly why and how far to take it." 

She folds her arms and awaits your reply, her expression measuring and curious.

Ishiza preens his feathers, though it looks like he's hiding his face under his wing.

"They have a special room here for ranking officers. And their guests.

"It's... more of a closet, really."
"I think we can do better than a soiled military cot in a tavern."
"Look who grew some standards all of a sudden." Maia breaks into a grin.

Hesitating a moment, Maia drags you into a hug and squeezes you like she's clinging to a mast in stormy weather. 

When she releases you, she has to catch her breath and tidy up her bun.
"Captain." She clears her throat.
"I wouldn't be half the captain I am without you at my side."
"That sort of talk is just begging for mutiny." Maia clucks her tongue with disapproval.
"Well? I've laid out my thoughts. You must have a couple."
"I like you, Maia. Let's see where this goes."
"I'm flattered, but let's keep this professional."
"Be a pleasure, captain." The edges of Maia's mouth crack with a repressed smile.
"Ishi, wouldn't you rather take a peck out of Tekēhu?"
Blinking with dawning comprehension, Ishiza slowly turns to face Tekēhu.

"This shark will decide who eats him and when, I say." 

Tekēhu folds his arms and glowers down at Ishiza.
"Well. Someone's been doing their morning stretches." Maia dabs a bead of sweat from her brow and clears her throat.
"Being a captain, a Watcher, and the gods only know what else must be thirsty work. Well done."
"Well done yourself, soldier."
"Ow. Take it easy next time."
"Scrambling to keep alive in these parts is good for staying in shape."
"Enough of that, soldier. We have work ahead of us."
"No promises, captain. You better learn to keep up with me."
"Always nice hearing that from an officer."

"Time to ship off and see what the Deadfire throws at us next."

Looking accomplished and refreshed, Maia knits her fingers together to crack her knuckles.
"Aye aye, captain."
"Don't I know it!"
